AU: Nakayama, M; Itoh, K; Takahashi, E
AF: Nakayama, M; Itoh, K; Takahashi, E
TI: Cyclophosphamide-induced bacterial translocation in Escherichia coli C25-monoassociated specific pathogen-free mice
DE: bacterial translocation; macrophage; cyclophosphamide; M-cells
ID: GASTROINTESTINAL TRACTS; LYMPH-NODES; ORGANS
AB: The kinetics of bacterial translocation (BTL) from the intestine to the mesenteric lymph nodes (MLN) and the number of peripheral white blood cells (WBC), macrophages in Peyer's patches (PP) and M-cells on the surface of cecal PP after cyclophosphamide (CY) injection were examined in penicillin-G and streptomycin sulfate decontaminated and Escherichia coli C25-monoassociated specific pathogen-free mice. WBC were counted to confirm the immunological state of the mice, Until 8 days after CY injection, the number of WBC, bacteria in MLN and macrophages in PP decreased, but then significantly increased on day 14. The levels again decreased to the control levels on day 16. Although the number of M-cells decreased up to day 8, it did not return to the control level on day 16. These results indicate that BTL is stimulated in an immunopotentiated state after CY injection, and this phenomenon may be closely related to the number of macrophages in the blood and PP.

TI: Genetic analysis of the capsid region of human astrovirus serotype 3 isolated in Japan
DE: astrovirus; virus capsid; serotype; sequence
ID: CHAIN-REACTION AMPLIFICATION; REVERSE TRANSCRIPTION; ENZYME-IMMUNOASSAY; RNA SEQUENCE; GASTROENTERITIS; ROTAVIRUSES; PREVALENCE; PROTEIN
AB: The total capsid region of astrovirus serotype 3 was analysed using five isolates including four from Japan and one from the United Kingdom. The nucleic acid and deduced amino acid sequences in the region were homologous (over 97%). However, the sequences of serotype 3 were different from those of serotypes 1, 2, 4, 5, 6 and 8, especially in the C terminus.

AU: Hashido, M; Lee, FK; Nahmias, AJ; Kawana, T
AF: Hashido, M; Lee, FK; Nahmias, AJ; Kawana, T
TI: Prevalence of herpes simplex virus type 1- and 2-specific antibodies among the acute, recurrent, and provoked types of female genital herpes
DE: HSV glycoprotein G; genital herpes; immunodot
ID: GLYCOPROTEIN-G; INFECTIONS; WOMEN; ASSAY
AB: Sixty-eight sera from the acute, recurrent, and provoked types of female genital herpes were compared for the seroprevalence of herpes simplex virus (HSV) types 1 and 2 by immunodot assay using HSV glycoprotein G. In the HSV-l-isolated patients, no HSV-2 antibodies were detected, whereas in the HSV-2-isolated patients, HSV-1 seroprevalence was 9% for the acute type, 89% for the provoked type (P<0.005), and 55% for the recurrent type (P<0.05). The natural history of female genital herpes and the possible protective role of pre-existing antibodies in preventing the acquisition or clinical manifestation of a subsequent HSV infection are discussed.

AU: Giangaspero, M; Harasawa, R; Verhulst, A
AF: Giangaspero, M; Harasawa, R; Verhulst, A
TI: Genotypic analysis of the 5'-untranslated region of a pestivirus strain isolated from human leucocytes
DE: bovine diarrhea virus; genotype; human; pestivirus
ID: VIRAL DIARRHEA VIRUS; NUCLEOTIDE-SEQUENCE; MOLECULAR-CLONING; RNA; GENOME; IDENTIFICATION
AB: The 5'-untranslated genomic region of the pestivirus strain Europa, originated in human leucocytes and previously identified as bovine diarrhea virus (BVDV), was amplified by reverse transcription-PCR and sequenced. Analyses based on primary nucleotide sequence homology and on secondary palindromic sequence structures characteristic to genotypes revealed that this human isolate should be assigned to a novel genotype of pestivirus, type Ic. This newly emerged genotype was related to, but distinguishable from the three known BVDV genotypes, Ia, Ib and II. Three other bovine field isolates of BVDV originated from Germany were also found to belong to this new genotype Ic. Within pestivirus genotype Ic strains, the overall nucleotide sequence homology was 95-96%, and 88-92%, 88-90% and 77-79% with the other BVDV genotypes Ia, Ib and II, respectively. With the strains from border disease virus (genotype III) and hog cholera virus (genotype IV), homologies were less than 75%.

TI: Application of equine infectious anemia virus core proteins produced in a baculovirus expression system to serological diagnosis
DE: equine infectious anemia virus; gag and p26 proteins; protein expression; recombinant baculovirus
ID: LINKED IMMUNOSORBENT-ASSAY; RECOMBINANT BACULOVIRUS; GAG GENE; PARTICLES; POLYPEPTIDES; RELATEDNESS; PRECURSOR; ANTIBODY; PR55GAG; RELEASE
AB: Equine infectious anemia virus (EIAV) core proteins were obtained from a baculovirus expression system, Recombinant baculoviruses (rBVs) highly expressed the Gag precursor and p26 antigens in an rBV-infected Sf21 cell culture supernatant. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and agar gel immunodiffusion (AGID) were conducted using the expressed proteins to detect antibodies from experimentally infected horses, The expressed antigens showed low background levels, high specificity and sensitivity in ELISA and AGID, The results of the serological tests using the expressed antigens were identical to those using a manufactured trial antigen. rBVs containing gag and p26 genes were found to express high quality and large quantities of Gag and p26 antigens, respectively, The antigens were quite useful for detecting anti-EIAV antibodies from virus-infected horses.

AU: Maruyama, S; Kinbara, H; Hayashi, H; Kimura, D
AF: Maruyama, S; Kinbara, H; Hayashi, H; Kimura, D
TI: Photoionized TOF mass spectrometry of atomic clusters
CT: 1996 US/Japan Joint Meeting on Molecular and Microscale Transport Phenomena
AB: Generation of carbon, silicon, and silver clusters by a laser-vaporization supersonic expansion cluster beam source was studied using a reflectron-type time-of-flight (TOF) mass spectrometer. The atomic cluster was generated by the laser vaporization of a solid sample disk, followed by cooling with supersonic expansion of pulsed helium gas. The neutral cluster, carried by helium gas, was ionized by a fourth harmonic Nd:YAG laser and accelerated by high voltage to the reflectron mass spectrometer. Positive-ion TOF mass spectra of carbon, silicon, and silver clusters were compared for several cluster source nozzle conditions. Helium gas pressure at the time of vaporization of solid material played the key role in cluster size range obtained. The effect of pressure was thoroughly examined for a relatively large carbon cluster, which was regarded as fullerene.

TI: A measurement of the N-2 number density and the N-2 vibrational rotational temperature in the lower thermosphere - Instrumentation and preliminary results
SO: MIDDLE AND UPPER ATMOSPHERES: SMALL SCALE STRUCTURES AND REMOTE SENSING
CT: C1-2 and C1-3 Symposia of COSPAR Scientific Commission C on Middle and Upper Atmospheres - Small Scale Structures and Remote Sensing, at 31st COSPAR Scientific Assembly
SP: Comm Space Res, Comm Space Res, Sci Comm Solar Terrestrial Phys
AB: The vibrational temperature (T-v) and the rotational temperature (T-R) of atmospheric molecular nitrogen were measured in situ by a sounding rocket S-310-24 in the lower thermosphere, 100 - 160 km above Uchinoura, Kagoshima, Japan (31.1 degrees N, 131.3 degrees E), at 20:00 JST on February 11, 1996. Molecular nitrogen was first ionized using an electron gun (1 keV, 2 mA) and the emission of the ist Negative Band (1NG) of the ionized N-2 was measured by a sensitive spectrometer, Preliminary analysis shows that the rotational temperature nearly follows the MSIS86 atmospheric model, but shows a peak at a height of 120 km that is 100 K hotter than MSIS86. (C) 1997 COSPAR.

AU: Kimura, H; Meshitsuka, G

TI: Contribution of benzyl ether bonds to carbohydrates to delignification-resistant nature of lignin in kraft pulp
DE: kraft pulp; residual lignin; delignification; benzyl ether band; pivaloyl iodide
ID: PHENOLIC HYDROXYL-GROUPS; WOOD
AB: It is well-known that a part of the lignin in wood is quite resistant to delignification even at the end of kraft pulping. As one of the possible reasons for this nature, the benzyl ether bonds of nonphenolic structural units in lignin to carbohydrate were proposed earlier. In this paper, contribution of these bonds are confirmed by their selective cleavage with pivaloyl iodide. As a counterpart of the ether bond, xylan strongly was indicated.

AU: Ishikawa, A; Wada, M; Igarashi, K; Samejima, M; Kuga, S; Okano, T
AF: Ishikawa, A; Wada, M; Igarashi, K; Samejima, M; Kuga, S; Okano, T
TI: Effects of cellulase treatment on tensile properties of ramie fiber
CT: 46th Annual Meeting of the Japan-Wood-Research-Society
SP: Japan Wood Res Soc
DE: ramie fiber; cellulase; tensile strength; node-like structure
ID: ENZYMATIC-HYDROLYSIS
AB: Effects of cellulase treatment on structural and tensile properties of ramie fiber were investigated. The tensile strength of ramie fiber decreased drastically by a cellulase treatment causing a small weight loss of the fiber. Scanning electron microscopic observations showed no significant morphological changes, but confocal laser scanning microscopy of the enzyme-treated samples stained with cellobiose dehydrogenase showed the formation of characteristic nodelike structures at every 30-50 mu m along the fiber axis. Fracture planes of enzyme-treated ramie fiber tends to run vertical to the fiber axis, whereas that of untreated fiber tends to be more irregular and oblique. Prolonged enzyme treatment resulted in spontaneous disintegration of the fiber into short fragments with vertically cut ends. These observations suggest that enzymatic attacks on ramie fiber results in the formation of node-like defects with a periodicity of 30-50 mu m along the fiber, which in turn cause significant deterioration in tensile strength.

AU: Kubojima, Y; Yoshihara, H; Ohta, M; Okano, T
AF: Kubojima, Y; Yoshihara, H; Ohta, M; Okano, T
TI: Accuracy of the shear modulus of wood obtained by Timoshenko's theory of bending
DE: shear modulus; Timoshenko's theory; Goens's approximation; resonance mode; length/depth ratio
ID: FLEXURAL VIBRATION
AB: The object of this study was to examine the influences of the length/depth ratio of a rectangular beam and the resonance modes used for the calculation of the shear modulus obtained by the Timoshenko's theory of bending. Flexural vibration tests were made with rectangular beams of 12 species with various elastic moduli. The values of the length/depth ratios which were needed were obtained by decreasing the thicknesses of the specimens. The shear moduli were calculated using the Mead-Joannides method. The Young's moduli for this calculation were measured by longitudinal vibration tests. The shear moduli obtained from the flexural vibration tests were compared with those by the torsion tests. The shear moduli by the Mead-Joannides method differed from those by the torsional vibration tests when the resonance mode numbers were small or the length/depth ratios were large. This tendency was clear when the values of the Young's modulus/shear modulus ratios were small. On the hypothesis that the measurement error was already contained in the Young's modulus, we developed an equation which determined the length/depth ratio and the minimal number of resonance modes for lessening the error level of the shear modulus.

AU: Yoshihara, H; Ohta, M
AF: Yoshihara, H; Ohta, M
TI: Analysis of the shear stress shear strain relationships in wood obtained by torsion tests
DE: shear stress; shear strain; torsion test; rectangular bar; strain-incremental theory
AB: In our previous paper, we proposed an equation for representing the shear stress/shear strain relationship of wood from torsion test data of a rectangular bar. However, the applicability of our proposal was limited by the aspect ratio and the degree of orthotropy of specimen. In this paper, we propose a new equation considering the aspect ratio and the orthotropy of the specimen. Torsion tests were made using the specimens of Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis Carr.) according to the following two series. In the first series, specimens with various aspect ratios were twisted around the longitudinal axis. In the other series, specimens with various angles between the grain and geometrical axes in cross-section were twisted around the radial axis. We compared the shear stress/shear strain relationships given from the torsion tests with those predicted from the equivalent stress/equivalent plastic strain relationship, and propose a new equation based on the comparisons. In spite of the rough approximation, the new proposal can represent the shear stress/shear strain relationships of wood specimens under various testing conditions.

AU: Yoshihara, H; Ohta, M
AF: Yoshihara, H; Ohta, M
TI: Stress-strain relationship of wood in the plastic region .3. Determination of the yield stress by formulating the stress-plastic strain relationship
DE: yield stress; stress strain relationship; uniaxial compression test; plastic region; formulation
ID: BEHAVIOR; BONE
AB: In this paper, we propose a method of determining the yield stress of wood by formulating the stress-strain relationship in the plastic region, and examined the applicability of this method by the results of uniaxial compression tests. Agathis (Agathis sp.) and katsura (Cercidiphyllum japonicum Sieb. and Zucc.) with various grain orientations were used for the specimens. These specimens were uniaxially compressed, and the stress (sigma)-plastic strain (epsilon(p)) relationships were formulated by Ludwik's power function. Swift's power function, and Voce----Palm's exponential function. The yield stress was obtained for each function with the stress value at epsilon(p)=0. Additionally, the yield stresses were given by three conventional methods for determining the yield stress (Reily.Burstein's method, 0.1%-strain offset method, and 5%-reduced modulus method), and were compared with those given by the proposed method. The results are summarized as follows: (1) The yield stresses obtained by the conventional methods were estimated as being large. By using these yield stresses, hence, the stress strain relationships in the plastic region would not be expressed properly. (2) Although the yield stress obtained by the stress plastic strain formula was influenced by the used function, the yield stress can be determined objectively when the relationship is formulated properly by the function.

AU: Kubojima, Y; Okano, T; Ohta, M
AF: Kubojima, Y; Okano, T; Ohta, M
TI: Effect of annual ring widths on structural and vibrational properties of wood
CT: 45th Annual Meeting of the Japan-Wood-Research-Society
SP: Japan Wood Res Soc
DE: annual ring width; density; fine structure; Young's modulus; loss tangent
ID: ACOUSTICAL PROPERTIES; SITKA SPRUCE
AB: The objective of this study was to make clear the relationships between annual ring widths, structures, and vibrational properties experimentally. Fourteen logs of Norway spruce (Picea abies Karst.) with various annual ring widths grown at the Tokyo University Forest in Hokkaido were used. To measure Young's modulus, loss tangent, crystallinity index, fibril angle,; and density distribution, free-free flexural vibration tests, X-ray diffractometry, and soft X-ray measurements were made. The density and crystallinity index had negative correlations to annual ring width, and fibril angle had positive correlation to annual ring width. Young's modulus had positive correlations to density and the crystallinity index and a negative one to fibril angle. Hence, we thought that when the growth speed was slow, density and the crystallinity index were large and the fibril angle was small, as a result, Young's modulus became large. On the other hand, the loss tangent did not have a clear correlation to other properties as did Young's modulus.

AU: Saito, K; Nakanishi, TM; Matsubayashi, M; Meshitsuka, G
AF: Saito, K; Nakanishi, TM; Matsubayashi, M; Meshitsuka, G
TI: Development of new lignin derivatives as soil conditioning agents by radical sulfonation and alkaline-oxygen treatment
DE: soil conditioning agent; modified lignin; aluminium ion; neutron radiography; radical sulfonation
ID: SUBSOIL HORIZONS
AB: It is well known that aluminium ions eluted into soil solutions under acidic conditions are toxic for plants. Such soil containing excess aluminium ions are distributed in the tropics of South-East Asia, and prevent cultivation and reforestation. To develop anew soil conditioning agent from lignin, kraft lignin was modified by radical sulfonation and alkaline-oxygen treatment, and its ability as a soil conditioning agent was examined. Lignins modified by radical sulfonation showed sequestering abilities for aluminium ions in the range of pH 4.0-5.6, and the growth rate of radish roots measured by neutron radiography and the line intersection method indicated that the modified lignin was able to remove the toxic effect of aluminium ions and even to improve the growth rate of the radish roots.

AU: Nishimura, T; Okuma, M
AF: Nishimura, T; Okuma, M
TI: Development of low-density wood based boards considering the distribution of elements .2. Bonding forces and void distributions among elements of wave-element boards
DE: low-density board; wood based board; wave-element; bonding force; void distributions
AB: Low-density wood based boards constructed with wave-elements were developed and their bonding forces and void distributions among elements were investigated. To be concrete, first, piled elements were tested in compression to study the influences of wave-elements' shapes on pressure caused in the hot-pressing process. Then, boards constructed with wave elements were tested in internal bonding (IB) and measurements of the distributions of voids among elements were made to study the influences of wave-elements' shapes on bonding forces and void distributions among elements. The results suggested that low-density boards made of wave-elements had a specific gravity of 0.2, whereas flat-elements did not make boards of a specific gravity below 0.25 because of not causing a bonding force among the elements. Because the specific gravities of wave-elements were 0.7, the lower limit of the compaction ratio to gain the mechanical property was 0.3. This value was less than the limit of the former compaction ratio of 0.5. Using wave-elements made it possible to equalize void distributions of boards.

AU: Niki, E
AF: Niki, E
TI: Mechanisms and dynamics of antioxidant action of ubiquinol
CT: 9th International Symposium on Biomedical and Clinical Aspects of Coenzyme Q
DE: ubiquinol; coenzyme Q; vitamin E; antioxidant; lipid peroxidation
ID: LOW-DENSITY-LIPOPROTEIN; VITAMIN-E; PEROXIDATION; TOCOPHEROL; INHIBITION
AB: The mechanisms and dynamics of antioxidant action of ubiquinol have been studied. Ubiquinol scavenges peroxyl radical faster than alpha-tocopherol. However, it is autooxidized rapidly to give hydroperoxyl radical and/or superoxide and hence its antioxidant potency is smaller than that of alpha-tocopherol. The side chain of ubiquinol reduces the mobility between the membranes. It was concluded that ubiquinol acts as a potent antioxidant in combination with alpha-tocopherol. (C) 1997 Elsevier Science Ltd.
